Legislators work to raise juvenile court age

New law would bump age up from 16 to 18

  • By Amanda Ruehlen and Elena Rue
  • Multimedia Journalists
Nov. 04 1:00 am
  • 15802 commentshttp%3A%2F%2Freesenews.org%2F2010%2F11%2F04%2Fjuvenile-justice%2F1580%2FLegislators+work+to+raise+juvenile+court+age2010-11-04+05%3A00%3A07Amanda+Ruehlenhttp%3A%2F%2Freesenews.org%2F%3Fp%3D1580
  • E-mail
  • Print

Do you like this story?

Juvenile Code

Sources

  • Ellie Kinnaird, N.C. Senator, D-Orange
  • Alice Bordsen, N.C. Representative, D-Alamance
  • Janet Mason, professor at UNC School of Government; legal facilitator to the Youth Accountability Task Force
  • Rob Thompson, director, Covenant with North Carolina’s Children
  • Brandy Bynum, director of policy and outreach, Action for Children
  • Cindy Cottle, psychologist, Raleigh
  • Eddie Caldwell, executive vice president, general counsel, North Carolina Sheriff’s Association
  • Peg Dorer, director, North Carolina Conference of District Attorneys
  • Olga Matos, parent

Correction: This article has been changed to reflect the correct number of people who signed a petition to raise the juvenile court age. The number is 1,800.

RALEIGH
North Carolina legislators and grassroots campaigns have joined the bipartisan effort to raise the minimum age of juvenile courts jurisdiction from 16-years old to 18-years old, a law that sets the state apart from the rest of the country and has been in place for more than 90 years.

“If it passes, this will be the most profound policy change North Carolina has passed in decades,” said N.C. Rep. Alice Bordsen, D-Alamance.

Bordsen, along with N.C. Sen. Ellie Kinnaird, D-Orange, is a co-chair on the Youth Accountability Task Force, which was created in 2009 to study the legal and economic logistics of moving the 31,000 16- and 17-year-olds from the adult system into the juvenile system.

In January, the task force’s findings and recommendations will be turned in to the N.C. General Assembly as a final report. A bill that implements this change is expected to be introduced in the 2011 session.

Currently, North Carolina and New York are the only states that automatically prosecute 16- and 17-year-olds as adults for criminal offenses, regardless of the severity of the crime. There are 10 states that try 17-years-olds as adults, and 38 that try 18-year-olds as adults.

Advocates say there are benefits to 16- and 17-year-olds being in the juvenile system rather than the adult system, like rehabilitation programs that include educational opportunities, mental health counseling and drug therapy.

“As a result, they are in a therapeutic system rather than a punitive system that will leave them without any advantage, assets, or resources,” Kinnaird said.

According to a 2007 study on youthful offenders by the state’s sentencing and policy advisory commission, 16- and 17-year-olds processed in adult court have higher rates of becoming repeat offenders along with an increased rate of violence.

In addition to the differences between the juvenile and adult systems, some advocates say that 16- and 17-year-olds have not finished developing neurologically, making it more likely that they will make mistakes.

“The frontal lobe, the front part of the brain, is not as developed in adolescents as it is in adulthood. [It] is the part that controls your impulses,” said Cindy Cottle, a psychologist in Raleigh who specializes in juveniles. “When we make decisions, we rely on our frontal lobe to stop us,” she said.

She said without this full neurological development, decision-making can be less rational and more impulsive.

Kinnaird said another reason 16- and 17-year-olds should be tried in the juvenile system is because their records would be confidential, but the records would not be confidential in the adult system.

“Many things cut you off if you have a felony conviction. Your life is essentially cut off right then,” Kinnaird said.

Bordsen said these records can lead to difficulties finding employment, securing affordable housing, admission to higher education and access to financial aid.

“It cripples them for their life,” Bordsen said.

One parent, Olga Matos, can attest to this. Her sons — Iran, Sergio and Pablo — were tried as adults in 2006 after getting in a fight when they were teenagers at an arcade in Wake County.

She said Iran recently lost his job at a hotel because the management was uncomfortable with his record, and that Sergio and Pablo are in jail for different crimes.

“When they get themselves in the mess, they still deserve a chance,” Matos said.

Kinnaird said one of the challenges of raising the age limit for the juvenile system is educating the public and legislators about juvenile jurisdiction. She said this effort is what could delay passing the bill.

“It’s not likely to be passed quickly,” she said. “It’s likely to take the entire two-year term.”

She said the task force has been working for more than a year to educate themselves, and now they have to transfer their knowledge to the public.

Nonprofits have joined this educational effort, and many have taken a grassroots approach.

Rob Thompson, director of the Covenant with North Carolina’s Children, said his organization is traveling around the state to record video stories of parents and kids that have been affected by juvenile jurisdiction. He said they plan to share these videos with legislators.

“We’re not even giving these kids a chance,” Thompson said. “The story I hear over and over again is a kid gets kicked out of school and gets a permanent record. They are just kind of screwed for one little thing that happens,” he said.

Brandy Bynum, director of policy and outreach for Action for Children, said the organization has been hosting community forums across the state for several years to educate people on juvenile justice.

“It’s all about getting people to engage and be aware that this is an issue in our state,” Bynum said.

Her organization has also been circulating an online petition, which currently has 1,800 signatures, to raise the age to 18.

But along with garnering public support, another problem lies in convincing people this reform is a good idea in view of a tight budget, Kinnaird said.

“The next challenge we have is the budget problem. It’s hard to convince people to spend money now and save money later.”

Kinnaird admitted that there are costs associated with raising the age, like enlarging juvenile facilities, hiring more staff, creating programming for 16- and 17-year-olds and separating adult and juvenile facilities.

She said that while these costs are upfront, the payoff will be greater in the long run.

In 2009, the Governor’s Crime Commission contracted the ESTIS Group, a public policy consulting group, to perform a cost-benefit framework to analyze the implications of moving 16- and 17-year-olds from the adult system to the juvenile system.

They found that if the juvenile system were enhanced with more evidence-based programs, the monetary benefits of raising the age could outweigh costs by about $7.1 million.

“We won’t have to build more $150 million prisons or house more people as adult criminals,” Kinnaird said.

According to the North Carolina Conference of District Attorneys, the average cost per day per bed to house an offender in a Department of Corrections prison facility is $63.56, while the cost per day per bed of a juvenile detention center is $174.00 and the cost per day per bed of a youth development center is $224.16.

Bordsen said the work group within the task force working to analyze costs is not able to predict a dollar amount for the total costs associated with raising the age. But she said the Eckerd Family Foundation, based in Florida, has provided the funds for a cost-benefit analysis performed by the Vera Institute of Justice. She said these numbers will be available by the time the recommendation is made in January.

The cost factor is also an issue for some of the effort’s biggest critics — law enforcement and district attorneys.

Eddie Caldwell, the executive vice president and general counsel of the North Carolina Sheriff’s Association, said the juvenile justice department already lacks adequate resources.

“It makes no sense to give them two more age groups of clientele to serve when they don’t have the resources to serve those they have now,” Caldwell said.

The North Carolina Conference of District Attorneys has similar concerns.

“This will be an enormous cost to taxpayers and may have a deleterious effect on an already-overburdened juvenile system,” Peg Dorer, the conference’s director, stated in an e-mail.

Janet Mason, a professor from the UNC-Chapel Hill School of Government who was brought onto the task force for an outside perspective, also said the biggest challenge to implementing change to the juvenile system is the lack of state resources.

“Nobody wants to do it if the resources to do it well aren’t there,” Mason said. No one wants to move this population of 16- and 17- year-olds into the juvenile system if all the things that are needed to give them the special kind of attention aren’t available,” she said.

To account for this, Mason said the legal work group within the task force considered a specific transfer procedure of the 16- and 17-year-olds from the adult system to the juvenile system.

Bordsen said the task force is proposing the change to happen in phases of four to six years. She said the first year would only move 16- to 16 ½ -year-olds from the adult system to the juvenile system. After that transfer, they could stop and evaluate before moving the next phase to the juvenile system.

Beyond the questions of cost still remains the idea of differentiating between the severity and frequency of crimes committed by 16- and 17-year-olds.

“To take a career criminal who has been breaking into houses since he was 16 would not be tough on crime,” Caldwell said. “It would be foolish.”

According to a 2007 study on youthful offenders by the state’s sentencing and policy advisory commission, 83.7 percent of the crimes committed by 16- and 17- year-olds are misdemeanors. Violent crimes against a person, known as class E felonies and above, only account for 2.8 percent.

To account for this smaller population of violent 16- and 17- year-olds who have committed violent crimes, Mason said the task force came up with a compromise.

“The working group made a recommendation to the task force, and that recommendation was that 16- and 17- year-olds be treated as juveniles, but that if they are charged with anything as serious as an E felony or above, and if the juvenile court found probable cause, then a transfer to the adult system would be mandatory,” Mason said.

Kinnaird said that once she got to know the system better, she realized that reform was a no-brainer: if legislators intervene early with effective treatment, then they could prevent ruining the lives of children across the state.

“The important thing,” she said, “is what happens down the road when lives are not ruined and people don’t get involved in a never-ending cycle of prison.”

Amanda Ruehlen, a senior from Concord, N.C., is a platform producer for the Reese Felts Digital News Project.
